attributes.title: Simple Linear Regression For Simple Soul

out.body:
Okay! Linear regression, the basic of the regression analysis. There are surely better implementations of linear regression in some other language that is faster and more intuitive than the one that we will be writing. So why would anyone want another linear regression implementation?. I don't have an answer to be honest, this is from a project that I am currently working on, and I thought maybe I could share it here, as there lacked a connection between the implementation side and the mathematical side of linear regression. Here we will be looking at the maths and at the same time implement that maths into code. The codes will be choppy as this is an initial prototype (classic excuse) so sorry about that!!

Maths?!

The wikipedia page for linear regression is the best summary on linear regression. The maths is concrete and clear to understand as it needs only the basic understanding of matrices and linear algebra. Okay! So let's get into just a bit of maths and then a bit of coding in between.

Linear regression ,as the name suggests, predicts the relation between a dependent variable yyy based on a single or set of explanatory variables xxx under the assumption that the data is linear. We know that a linear equation is given as: y=mx+cy = mx + cy=mx+c so in a linear regression we are trying to predict the mmm parameter which I prefer to call θ\thetaθ as it is just the slope. So linear regression boils down to finding the slope of the given data. This is everything that you need to know tbh, other things just naturally follow as we code along.

Maths into Code`

This blog will produce the most basic form of linear regression. Our optimizer will be gradient descent method , which is just betting against the gradient until we win or go bust. Quick formula for gradient descent (I love writing formula in LaTeX\LaTeXLATE​X, sorry cannot help).

xn+1=xn−γnΔF(x)x_{n+1} = x_n - \gamma_n \varDelta F(\relax{x})xn+1​=xn​−γn​ΔF(x)

Here, ΔF(x)\varDelta F\relax(x)ΔF(x) is the gradient of the function F(x)F \relax(x)F(x), γn\gamma_nγn​ is a often called a step-size. SGD is used all over the place, and it is also the father of other optimization methods like Adam. Enough with this jargon lets get writing.

Okay! So the first thing that we need is basic amount of matrix algebra. Lets say we want to predict a dependent variable $$y$$ based on explanatory variables XXX. Lets say that we have ppp numbers of features that we can predict our results from and there are nnn number of samples.

So the explanatory matrix (XXX) can be given as,

X=(x11⋯x1px21⋯x2p⋮⋱⋮xn1⋯xnp) X = { \begin{pmatrix} x_{11} & \cdots & x_{1p} \\ x_{21} & \cdots & x_{2p} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ x_{n1} & \cdots & x_{np} \end{pmatrix} } X=⎝⎛​x11​x21​⋮xn1​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​x1p​x2p​⋮xnp​​⎠⎞​

The size of the matrix XXX is n×pn \times pn×p on wikipedia you will see a extra column at the beginning consisting of all 1s1s1s but we won't struggle with that here as this is a very simple implementation. In computer terms, XXX is what we feed to the model to predict from or train from depending on the situation.

Lets define the yyy now. So there can only be one prediction to a series of input features so the shape of prediction(dependent) matrix is n×1.n \times 1.n×1. In matrix terms,

y=(y1y2⋮yn) y = { \begin{pmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ \vdots \\ y_n \end{pmatrix} } y=⎝⎛​y1​y2​⋮yn​​⎠⎞​

This is the labels that we will be sending to the model to learn from and also the prediction we get from the trained model. Now the part that we predict, θ\thetaθ. The θ\thetaθ is of shape p×1p \times 1p×1 so that we can multiply it with XXX. As for two matrices to be able to multiply with each other the number of rows on second matrix must be equal to number of columns on second matrix. As a tradition here in this blog lets her is the matrix representation.

θ=(θ1θ2⋮θp) \theta = { \begin{pmatrix} \theta_1 \\ \theta_2 \\ \vdots \\ \theta_p \end{pmatrix} } θ=⎝⎛​θ1​θ2​⋮θp​​⎠⎞​

In this implementation we will be ignoring the ε\varepsilonε - error variable. Now combining all these things together, our final equation is given as:

y=Xθy = X\thetay=Xθ

(y1y2⋮yn)=(x11⋯x1px21⋯x2p⋮⋱⋮xn1⋯xnp)(θ1θ2⋮θp){ \begin{pmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ \vdots \\ y_n \end{pmatrix} } = { \begin{pmatrix} x_{11} & \cdots & x_{1p} \\ x_{21} & \cdots & x_{2p} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ x_{n1} & \cdots & x_{np} \end{pmatrix} } { \begin{pmatrix} \theta_1 \\ \theta_2 \\ \vdots \\ \theta_p \end{pmatrix} } ⎝⎛​y1​y2​⋮yn​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​x11​x21​⋮xn1​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​x1p​x2p​⋮xnp​​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​θ1​θ2​⋮θp​​⎠⎞​

(y1y2⋮yn)=(x11θ1+x12θ2+⋯+x1pθpx21θ1+x22θ2+⋯+x2pθp⋮xn1θ1+xn2+⋯+xnpθp) \begin{pmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ \vdots \\ y_n \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} x_{11}\theta_1+ x_{12}\theta_2+\cdots+x_{1p}\theta_p \\ x_{21}\theta_1+x_{22}\theta_2+\cdots+x_{2p}\theta_p \\ \vdots \\ x_{n1}\theta_1+x_{n2}+\cdots+x_{np}\theta_p \end{pmatrix} ⎝⎛​y1​y2​⋮yn​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​x11​θ1​+x12​θ2​+⋯+x1p​θp​x21​θ1​+x22​θ2​+⋯+x2p​θp​⋮xn1​θ1​+xn2​+⋯+xnp​θp​​⎠⎞​

This above equation is what we are trying to predict and the shape of the matrix is n×1n \times 1n×1. I am sorry about being unable to name the equation, I am unable to figure out the way to do it. So this function passes through origin,but this isn't optimal. The process of adding a y-intercept will be left for the reader as an exercise. Here is a hint though.

y=Xθ+εy = X\theta + \varepsilony=Xθ+ε

(y1y2⋮yn)=(x11⋯x1px21⋯x2p⋮⋱⋮xn1⋯xnp)(θ1θ2⋮θp)+(ε1ε2⋮εn) \begin{pmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ \vdots \\ y_n \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x_{11} & \cdots & x_{1p} \\ x_{21} & \cdots & x_{2p} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ x_{n1} & \cdots & x_{np} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \theta_1 \\ \theta_2 \\ \vdots \\ \theta_p \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \varepsilon_1 \\ \varepsilon_2 \\ \vdots \\ \varepsilon_n \\ \end{pmatrix} ⎝⎛​y1​y2​⋮yn​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​x11​x21​⋮xn1​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​x1p​x2p​⋮xnp​​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​θ1​θ2​⋮θp​​⎠⎞​+⎝⎛​ε1​ε2​⋮εn​​⎠⎞​

Enough with the maths jargon lets get to the code. Okay so lets make a structure that will represent the linear regression. Calling it Linear will be good right?

pub struct Linear {
    data: Array2<f64>,
    theta: Array2<f64>,
    label: Array2<f64>
}

We will be using Rust and a crate called ndarray. ndarray is great and intuative. I had worked with numpy before and ndarray is similar to it (but not really similar). Our data structure(Linear) contains a data array, a theta array and a label array. The label array will be used during training. The theta represents the parameter that our model will learn and this theta will be used to predict from the given data. Lets implement the Linear regression struct step by step.

impl Linear {
    pub fn new(data: Array2<f64>, label: Array2<f64>)-> Self {
        let theta = Array2::from_shape_fn((data.ncols(),1),|(_,_)| rand::random());
        Linear {data, theta, label}
    }
}

Here we created a new function that creates a Linear struct. I couldn't create a empty random matrix without using another crate, so here I am using a little hack(not really a hack though) to create a matrix of size n×1n \times 1n×1. Now on to the most important and the simplest part. Every code after this point will be written inside the impl block.

fn hypothesis(&self) -> Array2<f64> {
    let prediction = self.data.dot(&self.theta);
    prediction
}

Here we do our formula of matrix multiplication (y=Xθy = X\thetay=Xθ). We haven't talked about what inner product is, but we don't need a complete definition of it here. For our sake, inner product is the dot product for vector and matrix multiplication for matrix.

fn gradient(&mut self, gamma: f64, iter: i32) {
    for _i in 1..iter{
        let delta = ((self.hypo() - &self.label).reversed_axes().dot(&self.data)).reversed_axes() // long
            * (1/self.data.nrows()) 
            * gamma;
        self.theta = &self.theta - delta;
    }
}

The initialization of delta variable looks complex, but I promise if I had splited it into multiple lines, it would have looked even more worse. On that note, lets go step by step on how it it initialized. The delta here is the vectorized form of gradient descent that we saw earlier. Okay so now a bit of maths :).

The cost function for linear regression is defined as:

C=12m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)2 C = \frac{1}{2m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)^2 C=2m1​i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)2

This is the cost function which is the average of loss function(this is why we have 12m\frac{1}{2m}2m1​ there. The 222 doesn't matter, it is there to make the equation look prettier after we take the derivative). Here mmm is the number of rows. So, the gradient descent will optimize according to this cost function. Taking the derivative wrt. each θ\thetaθ. You can check out the derivation on the bottom of the page. I cannot guarantee that it is correct, as it is something I did, but it is intuitive?

δCδθ=1m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)x \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta} = \frac{1}{m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)x δθδC​=m1​i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)x

And then finally, relating this to the code above. (self.hypo() - &self.label) is the (hθ(xi)−yi)(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)(hθ​(xi​)−yi​) part. Then we reversed_axis, which is done to allow the multiplication between the afforementioned value and xxx. So the code marked long above is equivalent to the following expression.

∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)x \displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)x i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)x

Then, we divide it by self.data.nrows() as in the equation to get the final value. The extra gamma parameter is the step-size as in the equation

xn+1=xn−γnΔF(x)x_{n+1} = x_n - \gamma_n \varDelta F(\relax{x})xn+1​=xn​−γn​ΔF(x)

Now the final step, taking it all together. We subtract the delta from self.theta to get the new theta value. This is equivalent to the equation above. In terms of our code, the mathematical equation is given as:

θn+1=θn−γδCδθ\theta_{n+1} = \theta_n - \gamma \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta}θn+1​=θn​−γδθδC​

The iter parameter is the number of iteration, surprised? Okay now the final part, the training. Lets create a training function.

pub fn train(&mut self, alpha: f64, iter: i32) {
        self.gradient(alpha, iter);
}

This calls the gradient function with those parameters and it's done!! To predict results after training we can create a public function named predict and inner product the input data with the theta parameter in our struct.

pub fn predict(&self, input: Array2<f64>) -> Array2<f64> {
        input.dot(&self.theta)
}

And this is it. Everything is done. This is the simplest linear regression, now we can train and test it. The code for training and testing it is given below:

use ndarray::{self, Array, Array2, Ix2};

fn main() {
    let data = Array::range(1.0, 15.0, 1.0).into_shape((14, 1)).unwrap();
    let label = Array::range(1.0, 15.0, 1.0).into_shape((14, 1)).unwrap();
    let mut lin = Linear::new(data, label);
    lin.train(0.01, 3);
    let data = Array::range(11.0, 25.0, 1.0).into_shape((14, 1)).unwrap();
    println!("{:?}", lin.predict(data));
}

There are lot of roads one can go from here. We could add a error-var or create a different optimization algorithm. Thank you for reading, have a great day(or night). The derivation of the loss function is given as. Here, when we derivate the θ\thetaθ is θj\theta_jθj​ and the equation is hθ(xi)=θjXh_\theta\relax(x_i) = \theta_j Xhθ​(xi​)=θj​X but for simplicity sake we will be putting it as θ\thetaθ and hθ(xi)=θXh_\theta\relax(x_i) = \theta Xhθ​(xi​)=θX.

C=12m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)2 C = \frac{1}{2m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)^2 C=2m1​i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)2

Taking derivation wrt θ\thetaθ,

δCδθ=12m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)2dθ \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta} = \frac{\frac{1}{2m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)^2}{d\theta} δθδC​=dθ2m1​i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)2​

δCδθ=12m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)2dθ \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta} = \frac{1}{2m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m\frac{(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)^2}{d\theta} δθδC​=2m1​i=1∑m​dθ(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)2​

δCδθ=12m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)2d(hθ(xi)−yi)×d(hθ(xi)−yi)dθ \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta} = \frac{1}{2m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m\frac{(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)^2}{d(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)}\times\frac{d(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)}{d\theta} δθδC​=2m1​i=1∑m​d(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)2​×dθd(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)​

δCδθ=12m×2×∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)(dhθ(xi)dθ−dyidθ) \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta} = \frac{1}{\cancel{2}m}\times\cancel{2}\times\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i) \lparen \frac{dh_\theta\relax(x_i)}{d\theta} - \frac{dy_i}{d\theta}\rparen δθδC​=2​m1​×2​×i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)(dθdhθ​(xi​)​−dθdyi​​)

We know hθ(xi)=θXh_\theta\relax(x_i) = \theta Xhθ​(xi​)=θX and dyidθ=0\frac{dy_i}{d\theta} = 0dθdyi​​=0,

δCδθ=1m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)(dθXdθ) \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta} = \frac{1}{m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)(\frac{\cancel{d\theta} X}{\cancel{d\theta}}) δθδC​=m1​i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)(dθdθX​)

So we have,

δCδθ=1m∑i=1m(hθ(xi)−yi)X \frac{\delta C}{\delta \theta} = \frac{1}{m}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta\relax(x_i)-y_i)X δθδC​=m1​i=1∑m​(hθ​(xi​)−yi​)X
out.frontmatter:
title: Simple Linear Regression For Simple Soul
date: 2021-07-05

blog.title: Random Or Not to be Random
